Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Reconciling innovation and adaptation during ongoing range expansion
Award.AbstractNarration:
To what extent are current adaptations of animals shaped by past adaptations, random events, or current necessities? Why do some species have exceptional adaptive and invasive abilities while their relatives go extinct unable to cope with environmental change? The principal investigator will address these questions by studying a bird species that over the past seventy years had successfully colonized much of North America, acquiring the widest ecological range of any living bird and a range of diverse beak morphologies that enables it to survive in new environments. Capitalizing on recently discovered developmental mechanisms that produce such diversity, the principal investigator proposes and tests a novel explanation of how complex structures, such as avian beaks, can evolve rapidly and reversibly.

Over the last twenty years the principal investigator, in close collaboration with local ranchers, citizens, tribal councils of three Indian reservations, as well as college students, established a unique temporal sequence of study populations that span hundreds of miles on both slopes of the Rocky Mountain Continental Divide in Montana. This work has been broadly advertised because of the highly visible nature of bird invasions, the well-established local media contacts, and wide public involvement in this large-scale project. Further, the principal investigator will continue to capitalize on the specialized undergraduate recruitment program in the University of Arizona to train minority students in modern scientific approaches to real life biological problems of species invasion and adaptation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the biggest puzzles in biology is how organisms are able to adapt to changing environments and yet be robust against changing environments at the same time. The main barrier to resolving this puzzle empirically is the necessity to infer past historical processes from current end-points of evolutionary process. This project sought to overcome this limitation by studying evolution of adaptation directly, as a process, capitalizing on ongoing colonization of North America by one of the most successful avian invaders ? the house finch. Specifically, the investigators traced evolutionary changes in finch beaks ? composite morphological trait that changes readily, extensively, and reversibly to enable this species? survival across its newly acquired and exceptionally wide ecological range. First, integrating direct historical records and population genetics tools, the researchers delineated multiple historical sequences of populations produced during exceptional expansion of the species? geographical range. Second, they studied changes in beak form, function, and development along these historical sequences, specifically focusing on how previous adaptations affected the rate and pattern of evolution of subsequent adaptations. Third, the researchers developed novel molecular and analytical tools that enabled recognition of past functional and developmental associations in the architecture of present-day beaks. Capitalizing on this ability, they then sought to establish how past developmental and functional associations among beak components affected its current and future evolution. This work required extensive training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students in advanced laboratory methods. The main scientific contribution of this project was development of tools that enable understanding of organismal architecture that reconciles stability, needed for functioning, with change, needed for survival in changing environments. These tools will greatly accelerate our progress in understanding developmental mechanisms of avian evolution. Finally, the project created ample educational opportunities, capitalizing on substantial involvement of public in all aspects of fieldwork under this project and general public interest in biology of the most successful avian invader of the last century.
